Award.AwardTitle: Conference Proposal: Conference Grant Application for Thematic Programme on Random Geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
The thematic programme on Random Geometry will be hosted at Cambridge University, United Kingdom, from January 12 to July 3, 2015. The purpose of the programme is to bring together leading researchers from around the world to explore and develop the burgeoning field of Random Geometry, a new discipline of mathematics that lies at the intersection of probability, geometry, and analysis. Random Geometry uses tools from these fields to quantifiably study the rich geometrical structure of random metric spaces and the random processes that live within them. Random Geometry is interdisciplinary in nature, and the intellectual merit of the programme lies in its potential to establish a cross-fertilization of ideas within different areas of mathematics and connect these ideas with theoretical physics and other fields of science. Broader impact will be realized via this exchange of ideas across disciplines and through the training of a new generation of students to carry on the work in this important field.

In addition to enabling long-term collaborations between leading researchers, the programme will allow for the dissemination of new results with conferences on Conformally Invariant Scaling Limits (Jan 26-30, 2015), Random Graphs and Trees and their Applications (Mar 16-20, 2015), Random Planar Structures (April 20-24, 2015), and the Geometry of Random Walks and SLE (June 15-19, 2015). The programme will begin with an Instructional Workshop for Younger Researchers (Jan 12-23, 2015). Funds from this proposal will enable the participation of United States based students and junior researchers in these programs.

Conference website: www.newton.ac.uk/event/rgm

POR.DRECONTENT:
The programme on Random Geometry at the Isaac Newton Institute of Cambridge University was held from January - June 2015 to create a new state-of-the-art level of research in this exciting new field. In the last fifteen years spectacular progress has been made in studying the geometry of random processes, but at the same time this progress has pushed the field far beyond its traditional boundaries and has led to the development of radically new concepts and intuitions. The programme was held to fuse together these ideas into a consistent new theory that bridges probability, geometry, and analysis, and integrates these fields together in unexpected ways. Success in this objective relied crucially on the interdisciplinary nature of the programme and required ideas coming from complex analysis, circle packing tools, discrete geometry, mathematical physics, combinatorics, and algebra. The programme was remarkable for its level of interest from both mathematicians and theoretical physicists, and the far reaching applications it showed in both areas.

The scientific programme consisted of four workshops on related but different topics: Conformally Invariant Scaling Limits, Random Graphs and Trees and Applications, Random Planar Structures, and the Geometry of Random Walks and SLE. These subjects lie at the intersection of probability theory and theoretical physics and have connections with computer science. Each workshop was well attended with more than 100 participants, and several new and exciting results were discussed during this time. Several new collaborations were hatched as a result of these workshops, leading to new ideas and publications in top journals. Preprints can be found on the Isaac Newton Institute's website.

The programme also had a large educational component that greatly benefited young researchers. The programme began with an intensive school that enabled young researchers to learn about the subject in a unified way. This lead to a degree of interconnectedness between researchers that was cited as a key benefit of the programme. It also consisted of two research seminars per week that exposed participants to cutting edge ideas in an informal setting, and an active and well-attended reading group that explored new research areas for Random Geometry.

The present NSF funding was used to allow young researchers from US universities to attend the program and partake in its activities. This provided these researchers with a tremendous opportunity to branch out into new research fields and collaborate with scientists that they would not normally interact with. Particular effort was made to recruit younger women and minorities to the programme. The participation of these researchers will greatly further their education and train them to continue in this line of research for years to come.
